Requirements There are some requirements for running Zapping:
V4L, V4L2 or XVideo support for your card
A working Gnome desktop, with the common libraries
libunicode >= 0.4
If you have some required package missing, a good way to install them easily is getting a Ximian GNOME desktop, following this link.
Alternatively, if you have an RPM based distro, you can look for the packages using RPMFIND. Debian users can get the debian packages from testing and unstable, both maintained by Christian Marillat.
If you want to compile it, make sure you have the appropiate development packages installed. For example, if compiling complains about AM_PATH_LIBGLADE, make sure you have libglade-devel correctly installed.
The remote control plugin (alirc incarnation) needs the LIRC (Linux Infrared Remote Control) package. If not already part of your distribution you can download LIRC from http://www.lirc.org.
Downloading CVS To get the latest development version of zapping, you can access anonymously the cvs server. Remember that there is no warranty that it will even compile. This method is mainly for developers and people that want to have the very latest, probably very buggy, version. Use the following:
cvs -z3 -d:pserver:anonymous@cvs.zapping.sourceforge.net:/cvsroot/zapping login
You will be asked for a password, just hit return.
cvs -z3 -d:pserver:anonymous@cvs.zapping.sourceforge.net:/cvsroot/zapping co zapping.
This will checkout the latest zapping release, from now on you can use:
cvs -z3 -d:pserver:anonymous@cvs.zapping.sourceforge.net:/cvsroot/zapping update -P
to update your local copy of the repository.
You can also browse the CVS repository, or get daily snapshots of the CVS tree. Downloading HTTP You can get the releases through HTTP, just click on the desired release:
Release numberRelease dateDescription
0.6.0cvs 28.05.2001 I'm going away some days, this is a snapshot of what's in CVS. New features (apart from the usual improvements) are:
MPEG plugin: needs the package mp1e to be installed, it can be downloaded from the same place you download Zapping. It's still a bit experimental, but works stable for me.
Reworked capture code: The current one is much more extensible than the old one, and apparently faster.
Support for Interactive TV (eacem, atvef) triggers.
Rolling headers in Zapzilla.
Page (TTX, CC) classification in Zapzilla.
Updated de.po, help/de.
Support for YVU420 XVideo acceleration.
0.5.92 20.03.2001 Support for cards with chromakey (Matrox Marvel, Rainbow Runner and friends), build fixes, more TTX export improvements.
0.5.91 17.03.2001 Bug fixes for the previous release, faster capture mode under XVideo, better TTX export dialog.

07.12.2000 This release fixes some bugs in the XVideo support and adds a Debian package. Everybody that had problems with the previous release (Gdk-Error) should upgrade. There's a new option --no-xv for the completely broken XVideo drivers.
0.5.8 (RPM / BZ2) 03.12.2000 XVideo support, Russian freq table and Russian Cyrillic chars for Teletext. Screenshot plugin moved from PNG to JPEG. Added de.po, ru.po, updated es.po and fr.po. Bug fixes.
You can also see all the releases directly from the Sourceforge project page here.
Due to popular demand, the code that manages V4L and V4L2 has been published as a separate package. It is the module called tveng, and it is available from the Sourceforge project page.
